p.span: TOPOLOGY IN 2D CPN-1𝑁1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1} MODELS ON THE LATTICE:
A CRITICAL COMPARISON OF DIFFERENT COOLING TECHNIQUES∗normal-∗FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{~{}\ast}

div.p: B. Allésa⁣†𝑎†FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-a MULOP:dagger FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{a~{}\dagger}, L. Cosmaib⁣‡𝑏‡FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-b MULOP:ddagger FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{b~{}\ddagger}, M. D’Eliac⁢¶𝑐¶FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c ¶ FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{c~{}\lx@paragraphsign} and A. Papad⁢§𝑑§FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-d § FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{d~{}\lx@sectionsign}

INFN–Sezione di Milano, I–20133 Milano, Italy
INFN–Sezione di Bari, I–70126 Bari, Italy
Dipartimento di Fisica, Università di Pisa and INFN–Sezione di Pisa, I–56127 Pisa, Italy
Dipartimento di Fisica, Università della Calabria and INFN–Gruppo collegato di Cosenza,

div.p: Two-dimensional CPN-1𝑁1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1} models are used to compare the behavior of different cooling techniques on the lattice. Cooling is one of the most frequently used tools to study on the lattice the topological properties of the vacuum of a field theory. We show that different cooling methods behave in an equivalent way. To see this we apply the cooling methods on classical instantonic configurations and on configurations of the thermal equilibrium ensemble. We also calculate the topological susceptibility by using the cooling technique.

p.span: Partially supported by MURST and by EC TMR program ERBFMRX-CT97-0122.

div.p: Two–dimensional (2d) CPN-1𝑁1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1} models [1, 2] play an important role in quantum field theory since they represent a convenient theoretical laboratory to investigate analytical and numerical methods to be eventually exported to QCD. This is believed to be possible since these models have several important properties in common with QCD, for instance asymptotic freedom, spontaneous mass generation, confinement and topological structure of the vacuum [3]. In particular, the CPN-1𝑁1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1} vacuum, like the QCD one, admits instanton classical solutions. The non–trivial structure of the vacuum for the CPN-1𝑁1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1} models, as well as for QCD, can be probed by defining suitable operators, like the topological charge density and its correlators, and by applying the prescriptions of quantum field theory. Yet most of the observables relevant for the investigation of the vacuum topological structure of a theory are beyond the reach of perturbation theory. Therefore some approximation is needed which works also in the non–perturbative regime. So far, the most effective and comprehensive tool is represented by Monte Carlo simulations on a space–time lattice. The lattice approach for the study of the vacuum structure brings about a very delicate task, that of separating the quantum fluctuations at the level of the lattice spacing from the relevant long–distance topological ones in any given configuration of the thermal equilibrium ensemble. Indeed, trying to assign a topological charge to a thermal equilibrium configuration, treating on the same footing short–distance (quantum) fluctuations and long–distance (topological) ones, would even prevent the reaching of the continuum limit. One powerful technique, frequently adopted in the literature to study the topological structure of the vacuum, is the so–called cooling method [4]. The idea behind the cooling method is that the quantum fluctuations at the level of the lattice spacing of a given configuration can be smoothed out by a sequence of local minimizations of the lattice action, thus leading to a configuration where only the long–distance, topologically relevant fluctuations survive. When this procedure is performed on a set of well–decorrelated equilibrium configurations, it yields a “cooled” equilibrium ensemble on which the expectation values of topological quantities can be determined. The precise definition of a cooling procedure is however arbitrary to a large extent: the lattice action to be locally minimized can be chosen differently from the one used in the thermalization, the number of cooling steps is a free variable, driving or control parameters of the cooling can be introduced, and so on. Comparing the behavior of different cooling methods is an interesting issue, especially when a new cooling strategy is proposed.

The aim of the present work is to get insight into a new cooling method first adopted in Ref. [5] for the SU(2) gauge theory and to compare it with two other methods, already known in the literature, namely the “standard” [4] cooling and its controlled version adopted by the Pisa group (see for instance Ref. [6]). The new cooling method, as it will be pointed out in the next Section, follows a different strategy with respect to the other two and could possess various interesting features, inaccessible to the other two cooling methods, like for instance preserving instanton–anti-instanton (I–A) pairs with interaction energy smaller than a fixable value [5]. The test–field for this comparison will be provided by the CPN-1𝑁1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1} models, which have all the interesting topological properties of the SU(N𝑁italic-NN) gauge theories, but are much easier to simulate on a lattice.

The paper is organized as follows: in Section 2 we introduce the lattice action and the lattice discretization of the relevant topological quantities. In Section 3 we describe in detail the three cooling methods. In Sections 4 and 5 we discuss their performance on 1–instanton and I–A classical lattice configurations respectively. In Section 6 we consider their behavior on thermal equilibrium configurations and find a correspondence between the three cooling techniques. In Section 7 we determine the physical value of the topological susceptibility of CP99FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:9 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{9} using the new cooling method and compare the results to those from an alternative approach not based on cooling. Finally in Section 8 we draw our conclusions.

It is defined as the two–point zero–momentum correlation of the topological charge density operator q⁢(x)𝑞𝑥italic-q OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)q(x),

In the CPN-1𝑁1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1} model q⁢(x)𝑞𝑥italic-q OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)q(x) is a renormalization group invariant operator. Imposing that q⁢(x)𝑞𝑥italic-q OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)q(x) does not renormalize in the continuum generally implies a finite multiplicative renormalization Z𝑍italic-ZZ on the lattice [10]

Moreover, the lattice topological susceptibility χLsuperscript𝜒𝐿italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{L} in general does not meet the continuum prescription given in Eq. (5), thus leading to an additive renormalization which consists in mixings of χLsuperscript𝜒𝐿italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{L} with operators which have the same quantum numbers as χ𝜒italic-chi\chi,

div.p: where M⁢(β)𝑀𝛽italic-M OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)M(\beta) indicates such mixings. The extraction of χ𝜒italic-chi\chi from the lattice thus requires the determination of both the multiplicative and additive renormalizations, Z⁢(β)𝑍𝛽italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)Z(\beta) and M⁢(β)𝑀𝛽italic-M OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)M(\beta). This is a feasible task, as will be shown in Section 7, and in this way one obtains the so–called “field theoretical” determination of the topological susceptibility.

Alternatively one can use cooling to determine the topological susceptibility. This method will be described extensively in the next Section. The idea is that, by an iterative process of local minimization of the action, the quantum fluctuations at the scale of the ultraviolet cut–off, which are responsible for the renormalizations, are suppressed thus implying Z→1→𝑍1italic-Z ARROW:to NUMBER:1Z\to 1 and M→0→𝑀0italic-M ARROW:to NUMBER:0M\to 0 in Eq. (10) as the cooling iteration goes on, so that a2⁢χsuperscript𝑎2𝜒italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-chia^{2}\,\chi can be extracted directly from the measurement of χLsuperscript𝜒𝐿italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{L} after cooling, as it will be shown in Section 7.

A cooling step applied on a lattice configuration consists in assigning to every field variable a new value chosen in order to locally minimize the lattice action. The iteration of this procedure converges to a configuration which should represent a solution of the Euclidean classical equations of motion. In the continuum 2d CPN-1𝑁1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1} models, as well as in the case of 4d SU(N𝑁italic-NN) gauge theories, there are classical solutions that belong to a definite topological charge sector, identified by an integer value of the topological charge Q𝑄italic-QQ and by a finite action (S=2⁢π⁢|Q|/g𝑆2𝜋𝑄𝑔italic-S RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 italic-pi VERTBAR:| italic-Q VERTBAR:| MULOP:divide italic-gS=2\pi|Q|/g in the case of CPN-1𝑁1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1}). The classical solutions with Q≠0𝑄0italic-Q RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:0Q\neq 0 are called instantons or anti-instantons (depending on the sign of Q𝑄italic-QQ). On the lattice, owing to the artifacts introduced by the discretization of the theory, configurations with non–trivial topology can represent only approximated solutions of the lattice equations of motion. The common belief is that a moderately long cooling sequence can be able to wash out the quantum fluctuations of a given lattice configuration, so revealing the underlying metastable state with possible non–trivial topology, and that this state is the lattice counterpart of a continuum classical one. Of course, if the cooling is further protracted, the metastable state will eventually “decay” into the trivial vacuum. Stated in other words, once the quantum fluctuations have been eliminated and the topological bumps of a configuration (instantons or anti-instantons) have been revealed, if the cooling is further protracted then the isolated instantons or anti-instantons shrink, the I–A pairs annihilate and the configuration falls into the trivial vacuum of the lattice theory. In consideration of the above arguments, it is clear that a great care is needed in determining when a cooling iteration has to be stopped. Nevertheless, there is no way to prevent the loss of topological signal at lattice scales of the order of the lattice spacing, since topology at these scales cannot be distinguished from quantum fluctuations. It must be pointed out however, that any loss of topological signal due to cooling which occurs at fixed scales in lattice units becomes irrelevant in physical units as far as the coupling is tuned towards its critical value, i.e. in the continuum limit, when the lattice spacing a𝑎italic-aa tends to zero. This is not the case only when the instanton size distribution is singular in the short–distance regime, as in the 2d CP11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{1} model [11, 12].

In the case of the 2d CPN-1𝑁1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1} models, the cooling algorithm amounts to replacing at each lattice site x𝑥italic-xx the field variables z⁢(x)𝑧𝑥italic-z OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)z(x) and λμ⁢(x)subscript𝜆𝜇𝑥italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)\lambda_{\mu}(x) by new ones znew⁢(x)superscript𝑧new𝑥italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start new POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)z^{\mathrm{new}}(x) and λμnew⁢(x)superscriptsubscript𝜆𝜇new𝑥italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start new POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)\lambda_{\mu}^{\mathrm{new}}(x), chosen in order to locally minimize the lattice action, while the other field variables are left unchanged. A cooling step consists in a sweep through the entire lattice volume in order to apply this local minimization sequentially at every site x𝑥italic-xx. The terms in the action density which depend on z⁢(x)𝑧𝑥italic-z OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)z(x) and λμ⁢(x)subscript𝜆𝜇𝑥italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)\lambda_{\mu}(x) for a given lattice site x𝑥italic-xx have the form

It is easy to see that the local minimum of the lattice action is obtained when the new field variables coincide with the corresponding normalized forces:

div.p: with ||u||≡u¯⋅unorm𝑢⋅¯𝑢𝑢VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| italic-u VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| RELOP:equivalent-to italic-square-root ARG:start OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-u ARG:end MULOP:cdot italic-u ARG:end||u||\equiv\sqrt{\bar{u}\cdot u} for a generic complex number or N𝑁italic-NN–component vector u𝑢italic-uu (z⁢(x)𝑧𝑥italic-z OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)z(x), Fz⁢(x)subscript𝐹𝑧𝑥italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)F_{z}(x), λμ⁢(x)subscript𝜆𝜇𝑥italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)\lambda_{\mu}(x), Fλ⁢(x,μ)subscript𝐹𝜆𝑥𝜇italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-mu CLOSE:)F_{\lambda}(x,\mu), etc.). According to the supplementary conditions under which the above replacements are performed, we have different cooling procedures. The first cooling procedure, which we call “standard”, is the one where the replacements z⁢(x)→znew⁢(x)→𝑧𝑥superscript𝑧new𝑥italic-z OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) ARROW:rightarrow italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start new POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)z(x)\rightarrow z^{\mathrm{new}}(x) and λμ⁢(x)→λμnew⁢(x)→subscript𝜆𝜇𝑥superscriptsubscript𝜆𝜇new𝑥italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) ARROW:rightarrow italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start new POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)\lambda_{\mu}(x)\rightarrow\lambda_{\mu}^{\mathrm{new}}(x) are unconstrained. The second one, which we call “Pisa cooling”, is the one where the replacement of z⁢(x)𝑧𝑥italic-z OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)z(x) and λμ⁢(x)subscript𝜆𝜇𝑥italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)\lambda_{\mu}(x) is performed if the distance between the old and the new fields is smaller than a previously fixed parameter δPisasubscript𝛿Pisaitalic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Pisa POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta_{\rm Pisa}: ||λμ⁢(x)-λμnew⁢(x)||≤δPisanormsubscript𝜆𝜇𝑥superscriptsubscript𝜆𝜇new𝑥subscript𝛿PisaVERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start new POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Pisa POSTSUBSCRIPT:end||\lambda_{\mu}(x)-\lambda_{\mu}^{\mathrm{new}}(x)||\leq\delta_{\rm Pisa} and analogously for the z𝑧italic-zz fields, otherwise the new field is chosen to lie on the (z⁢(x),znew⁢(x))𝑧𝑥superscript𝑧new𝑥OPEN:( italic-z OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) PUNCT:, italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start new POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) CLOSE:)(z(x),z^{\mathrm{new}}(x)) ((λμ⁢(x),λμnew⁢(x))subscript𝜆𝜇𝑥superscriptsubscript𝜆𝜇new𝑥OPEN:( italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) PUNCT:, italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start new POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) CLOSE:)(\lambda_{\mu}(x),\lambda_{\mu}^{\mathrm{new}}(x))) plane, at a distance from z⁢(x)𝑧𝑥italic-z OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)z(x) (λμ⁢(x)subscript𝜆𝜇𝑥italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)\lambda_{\mu}(x)) exactly equal to δPisasubscript𝛿Pisaitalic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Pisa POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta_{\rm Pisa} [6]. The third cooling procedure, called “new cooling” in the following, was introduced in Ref. [5]. It consists in making the replacement only if the distance between the old and new fields is larger than a fixed parameter δ𝛿italic-delta\delta, otherwise the field is left unchanged. We observe that the three methods follow a different strategy. In particular, while the Pisa cooling acts first on the smoother fluctuations and the number of cooling iterations to be performed has to be fixed a priori, the new cooling performs local minimizations only if these fluctuations are larger than a given threshold and the iteration stops automatically when all the surviving fluctuations are smoother than the (lattice) threshold determined by the dimensionless parameter δ𝛿italic-delta\delta. It is easy to see that the new field variables differ from the old ones by terms which, in the continuum limit, are of order a2superscript𝑎2italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:enda^{2}, where a𝑎italic-aa is the lattice spacing. Therefore the parameter δ𝛿italic-delta\delta is expected to scale in the continuum limit like a quantity of dimension two.

figure.figcaption: Figure 1: θz⁢(x)subscript𝜃𝑧𝑥italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)\theta_{z}(x) (left) and θλ⁢(x,1)subscript𝜃𝜆𝑥1italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 CLOSE:)\theta_{\lambda}(x,1) (right) for an “artificial” 1–instanton with size ρ=10⁢a𝜌10𝑎italic-rho RELOP:equals NUMBER:10 italic-a\rho=10a placed in the middle of a 602superscript602NUMBER:60 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end60^{2} lattice.

div.p: In the following we will compare these three cooling methods in several contexts, namely on “artificial” 1–instanton configurations, on I–A pairs, on thermal equilibrium configurations and in the determination of the continuum topological susceptibility. Moreover we will establish a relation between the number of cooling iterations in the standard and Pisa coolings with the parameter δ𝛿italic-delta\delta of the new cooling and will discuss the validity of the picture of cooling as a diffusion process.

In the continuum CPN-1𝑁1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1} models, in the infinite 2d space–time, a 1–instanton configuration is a classical solution of the equations of motion characterized by a topological charge one and a finite action (S=2⁢π/g𝑆2𝜋𝑔italic-S RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 italic-pi MULOP:divide italic-gS=2\pi/g). The explicit form of a continuum 1–instanton configuration is

An “artificial” 1–instanton lattice configuration can be represented by the discretization of the above continuum configuration on a 2d finite volume lattice with periodic boundary conditions. In particular, we used the following expressions for the fields z𝑧italic-zz and λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda [1]

div.p: which correspond to choose u=(1,0,0,…)𝑢100…italic-u RELOP:equals OPEN:( NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, ID:dots CLOSE:)u=(1,0,0,\dots) and v=(0,1,0,0,…)𝑣0100…italic-v RELOP:equals OPEN:( NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, ID:dots CLOSE:)v=(0,1,0,0,\dots). Actually 1–instanton configurations cannot exist on a 2d torus even in the continuum [13] and they represent only approximate solutions of the classical equations of motion. This approximation becomes better and better as the ratio ρ/(L⁢a)𝜌𝐿𝑎italic-rho MULOP:divide OPEN:( italic-L italic-a CLOSE:)\rho/(La) decreases. On the lattice, this problem would lead to metastability even in the case of an ideally perfect discretization. However the above–defined artificial 1–instanton lattice configurations are enough for our purposes since they will be used only as test configurations for cooling methods and not to extract physical information.

The starting configuration is a 1–instanton with size ρ=10⁢a𝜌10𝑎italic-rho RELOP:equals NUMBER:10 italic-a\rho=10a placed in the middle of a 602superscript602NUMBER:60 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end60^{2} lattice.

div.p: In Fig. 1 we show the distribution of the angles θz⁢(x)subscript𝜃𝑧𝑥italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)\theta_{z}(x) and θλ⁢(x,1)subscript𝜃𝜆𝑥1italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 CLOSE:)\theta_{\lambda}(x,1) for an artificial 1–instanton with size ρ=10⁢a𝜌10𝑎italic-rho RELOP:equals NUMBER:10 italic-a\rho=10a located in the middle of a 602superscript602NUMBER:60 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end60^{2} lattice. These angles are defined as

semantics.annotation: VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start new POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| RELOP:equivalent-to NUMBER:2 TRIGFUNCTION:sine FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-mu CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| italic-z OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start new POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| RELOP:equivalent-to NUMBER:2 TRIGFUNCTION:sine FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PERIOD:.

div.p: It is clear that, while the standard cooling acts indistinctly on each lattice site, the Pisa cooling and the new cooling deform 1–instanton lattice configurations starting from different regions of the lattice. The new cooling will act first on the region around the center of the instanton, the Pisa cooling on the border regions. Therefore it is not obvious whether under the three coolings the configurations will look the same sweep after sweep. We did therefore the following check: we performed a long (O⁢(1000)𝑂1000italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:1000 CLOSE:)O(1000) steps) iteration of the standard and Pisa coolings111For the Pisa cooling we always use δPisa=0.2subscript𝛿Pisa0.2italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Pisa POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.2\delta_{\rm Pisa}=0.2, following Ref. [14]. on an artificial 1–instanton configuration with size ρ=10⁢a𝜌10𝑎italic-rho RELOP:equals NUMBER:10 italic-a\rho=10a and after each sweep we extracted the topological charge QLsuperscript𝑄𝐿italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{L}, the action SLsuperscript𝑆𝐿italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{L} and the size ρ/a𝜌𝑎italic-rho MULOP:divide italic-a\rho/a. This size was determined by a very local procedure, namely by looking for the maximum of the lattice action density smaxLsubscriptsuperscript𝑠𝐿maxitalic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:ends^{L}_{\mathrm{max}} and using the relation smaxL=2⁢a2/ρ2subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝐿max2superscript𝑎2superscript𝜌2italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ends^{L}_{\mathrm{max}}=2a^{2}/\rho^{2}, valid for a 1–instanton configuration. Then, starting from the same configuration, we applied the new cooling for δ𝛿italic-delta\delta as small as 5×10-45superscript104NUMBER:5 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end5\times 10^{-4} and for each configuration obtained during the cooling iteration, we determined again QLsuperscript𝑄𝐿italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{L}, SLsuperscript𝑆𝐿italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{L} and ρ/a𝜌𝑎italic-rho MULOP:divide italic-a\rho/a. Finally, we put on a plot QLsuperscript𝑄𝐿italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{L} and SLsuperscript𝑆𝐿italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{L} as functions of ρ/a𝜌𝑎italic-rho MULOP:divide italic-a\rho/a. The result is shown in Fig. 2: the values of QLsuperscript𝑄𝐿italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{L} and SLsuperscript𝑆𝐿italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{L} during the three cooling methods lie on the same curve. The same plot was obtained by using a different procedure to determine the size of the cooled configurations, namely a global fit of the lattice action density to the continuum expression for the action density of a 1–instanton configuration, Eq. (14). We interpret these results as an indication that the three coolings deformed in the same way the starting configuration. If this conjecture is correct, it should be possible to put into correspondence the δ𝛿italic-delta\delta parameter of the new cooling with the number of steps of the standard or Pisa coolings. This will be done in Section 6.

div.p: where ci(I,A)superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑖𝐼𝐴italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-I PUNCT:, italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endc_{i}^{(I,A)} is the i𝑖italic-ii–th coordinate of the center of the instanton or anti-instanton and ρ(I,A)superscript𝜌𝐼𝐴italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-I PUNCT:, italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\rho^{(I,A)} are their sizes. As “artificial” I–A lattice configuration we took the discretization of the above continuum configuration on a 2d finite volume lattice with periodic boundary conditions. For simplicity, we used ρ(I)=ρ(A)≡ρsuperscript𝜌𝐼superscript𝜌𝐴𝜌italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-I CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to italic-rho\rho^{(I)}=\rho^{(A)}\equiv\rho.

Starting from several I–A pairs with different values of the distance between the centers c(I)superscript𝑐𝐼italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-I CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endc^{(I)} and c(A)superscript𝑐𝐴italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endc^{(A)} and of the size ρ𝜌italic-rho\rho, we performed long cooling sequences with the three methods, namely O⁢(1000)𝑂1000italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:1000 CLOSE:)O(1000) iterations for the standard and Pisa coolings and δ𝛿italic-delta\delta as small as 5×10-45superscript104NUMBER:5 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end5\times 10^{-4} for the new cooling. In order to have an indication of how the cooling process works, we examined by eye the distribution of the topological charge and action densities during the different cooling iterations. The evolution of these densities looked the same, no matter which cooling procedure was adopted. Specifically, the distribution of the action density shows at the beginning two equal instanton bumps, which for d≫ρmuch-greater-than𝑑𝜌italic-d RELOP:much-greater-than italic-rhod\gg\rho (d𝑑italic-dd is the distance between the two centers c(I)superscript𝑐𝐼italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-I CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endc^{(I)} and c(A)superscript𝑐𝐴italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endc^{(A)}) are well–separated; then, as the cooling goes on, these bumps lower in height and merge together, up to complete annihilation. In order to make quantitative the statement that the three coolings behave essentially in the same way, we studied the shell correlation function of the topological charge density. This function is defined as G⁢(r)≡1/Nr⁢∑x,yqL⁢(x)⁢qL⁢(y)𝐺𝑟1subscript𝑁𝑟subscript𝑥𝑦superscript𝑞𝐿𝑥superscript𝑞𝐿𝑦italic-G OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) RELOP:equivalent-to NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x PUNCT:, italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-y CLOSE:){G}(r)\equiv 1/N_{r}\sum_{x,y}q^{L}(x)q^{L}(y) where the sum is extended over all pairs of sites x𝑥italic-xx, y𝑦italic-yy which satisfy r≤|x-y|<r+Δ⁢r𝑟𝑥𝑦𝑟Δ𝑟italic-r RELOP:less-than-or-equals VERTBAR:| italic-x ADDOP:minus italic-y VERTBAR:| RELOP:less-than italic-r ADDOP:plus Delta italic-rr\leq|x-y|<r+\Delta\,r and Nrsubscript𝑁𝑟italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{r} is the number of those pairs for a given value of r𝑟italic-rr (we have chosen Δ⁢r=0.6⁢aΔ𝑟0.6𝑎Delta italic-r RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.6 italic-a\Delta\,r=0.6\,a). We determined G⁢(r)𝐺𝑟italic-G OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:){G}(r) on every configuration resulting after each cooling iteration222From reflection positivity it follows that the two–point correlation function of the topological charge density, and consequently also ⟨G⁢(r)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝐺𝑟OPEN:langle italic-G OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle\langle G(r)\rangle, is negative at distances r>0𝑟0italic-r RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0r>0. However reflection positivity is lost during cooling, since cooling affects the quantum structure of the theory leaving only the semiclassical background intact. After cooling one in general obtains positive values for ⟨G⁢(r)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝐺𝑟OPEN:langle italic-G OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle\langle G(r)\rangle, apart from those large separations which the cooling procedure has not yet affected.. We compared the results which presented the same value for the internal energy E𝐸italic-EE which is defined by

semantics.annotation: italic-E RELOP:equivalent-to FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-z ARG:end OPEN:( italic-x ADDOP:plus OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-mu ARG:end CLOSE:) MULOP:cdot italic-z OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-z ARG:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) MULOP:cdot italic-z OPEN:( italic-x ADDOP:plus OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-mu ARG:end CLOSE:) OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-lambda ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) PUNCT:,

div.p: and is proportional to the lattice action. In Fig. 3 we show the behavior of the shell correlation versus E𝐸italic-EE during the three (protracted) coolings for the case of r𝑟italic-rr equal to the distance d𝑑italic-dd between the centers of the instanton and of the anti-instanton (left) and to the instanton (or anti-instanton) size ρ𝜌italic-rho\rho (right). The three curves fall on top of each other, apart from a small deviation between the Pisa cooling and the other two at the very first (1–2) cooling steps, due to (unphysical) finite size effects. Since the shell correlation of the topological charge density is related to the size of the instantons, the conclusion is that the three cooling methods perform equivalently in deforming the size of both the instanton and the anti-instanton in the I–A pair and in modifying the distance between the two peaks.

The new cooling results are reported versus equivalent iterations of standard cooling steps following Table 1. Full (open) symbols indicate the new (standard) cooling.

The data have been slightly horizontally shifted.

figure.figcaption: Figure 7: Action density for a configuration obtained by cooling a thermal equilibrium configuration of CP33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3} at β=1.05𝛽1.05italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.05\beta=1.05 on a 762superscript762NUMBER:76 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end76^{2} lattice by the new cooling with δ=0.007𝛿0.007italic-delta RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.007\delta=0.007 (left) and by 30 iterations of the standard cooling (right). The two amounts of cooling are equivalent in the sense explained in the text.

img.figcaption: Figure 8: Relation between the new cooling parameter δ𝛿italic-delta\delta and the number of standard cooling iterations n𝑛italic-nn, at β=1.05𝛽1.05italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.05\beta=1.05 on a lattice 762superscript762NUMBER:76 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end76^{2} in the CP33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3} model, together with a best fit to a function proportional to 1/n1𝑛NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-n1/n.

div.p: Using artificial configurations with non–trivial topology provides interesting suggestions about a cooling procedure, but in real life the cooling must be applied on thermal equilibrium configurations. Among them there are configurations which contain several instanton and anti-instanton bumps, merged in a sea of quantum fluctuations. These configurations can represent as well good test–fields for the different cooling procedures. Their evolution under cooling can be visualized by the distribution of the action density or of the topological charge density. In principle we could expect that the three cooling methods described in Section 3 make the starting thermalized configuration evolve along different directions. In particular, for a not too protracted cooling, one expects that all the three methods have been able to erase the quantum fluctuations, but the number, type and location of the surviving topological bumps in the cooled configuration can be rather different. In order to check this expectation, it is necessary to find a criterion to make a correspondence between the number of iterations in the standard or Pisa coolings with a δ𝛿italic-delta\delta parameter for the new cooling. We defined an effective temperature for configurations obtained during the cooling iteration in such a way that the comparison could be made only between configurations at the same temperature. The most natural “thermometer” is the internal energy E𝐸italic-EE, Eq. (21), since this is the quantity which is minimized during the cooling procedure.

We put into practice the above considerations in the case of the CP33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3} model. We generated by Monte Carlo a sample of equilibrium configurations on a 762superscript762NUMBER:76 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end76^{2} lattice at β=1.05𝛽1.05italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.05\beta=1.05. As in Ref. [14], the simulation algorithm is, for every updating step, a mixture of 4 microcanonical updates and 1 over heat–bath [17]. We measured the expectation value of E𝐸italic-EE on the cooled ensembles obtained by the three cooling methods after several number of iterations (standard and Pisa coolings) and for several values of δ𝛿italic-delta\delta (new cooling). By comparing the results and imposing that E𝐸italic-EE be the same, we obtained a correspondence table between the number of cooling iterations for the standard and Pisa coolings with a value of the δ𝛿italic-delta\delta parameter in the new cooling. We found for instance that for the CP33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3} model at the above values of β𝛽italic-beta\beta and lattice size, 30 iterations of the standard cooling correspond (in the sense of the average value of E𝐸italic-EE) to δ=0.007𝛿0.007italic-delta RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.007\delta=0.007 for the new cooling and to approximately 33 iterations of the Pisa cooling.

In general the matching between the number of standard and Pisa cooling iterations is not as good as the one obtained between δ𝛿italic-delta\delta in the new cooling and a fixed number of iterations in the standard (or Pisa) cooling. The reason is that in the second case one can tune a continuous parameter while in the first only integer jumps of the parameter controlling the amount of cooling are allowed. For this reason we have mainly investigated the relation existing between the standard and new coolings. In Table 1 we show the values of δ𝛿italic-delta\delta (new cooling) found in correspondence to several numbers of iterations of the standard cooling for the CP33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3} model at β=1.05𝛽1.05italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.05\beta=1.05 on a 762superscript762NUMBER:76 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end76^{2} lattice. Notice that a different correspondence table may be found for other values of N𝑁italic-NN and β𝛽italic-beta\beta.

Using the correspondence table we can directly compare the different coolings. As a first step, we have computed the average values of some physical quantities on samples obtained after applying equivalent amounts of cooling on a set of equilibrium configurations. In Fig. 4 we show the results for the lattice topological susceptibility with the standard and new coolings. By using the relation given in Table 1, we report both determinations in terms of the number of standard cooling iterations. It clearly appears that, regarding to the determination of the topological susceptibility, the two cooling techniques are completely equivalent.

div.p: is the lattice Fourier transform of the correlation of two local gauge–invariant composite operators Pi⁢j⁢(x)subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗𝑥italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)P_{ij}(x) which have been defined in Eq. (7) (the subscript “conn” means connected Green function). The results for χmsubscript𝜒mitalic-chi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\chi_{\rm m} and ξG/asubscript𝜉𝐺𝑎italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-a\xi_{G}/a from Fig. 5 indicate that in this case the new cooling and the standard cooling show a good agreement, apart from a small discrepancy at large numbers of iterations.

We have also studied the shell correlation of two lattice topological charge density operators, ⟨G⁢(r)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝐺𝑟OPEN:langle italic-G OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle\langle{G}(r)\rangle, for r/a𝑟𝑎italic-r MULOP:divide italic-ar/a going from 0 to 20, after equivalent amounts of the three coolings. In Fig. 6 we compare the standard cooling (30 iterations) to the new cooling (δ=0.007𝛿0.007italic-delta RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.007\delta=0.007) and the Pisa cooling (33 iterations, δPisa=0.2subscript𝛿Pisa0.2italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Pisa POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.2\delta_{\rm Pisa}=0.2)333See footnote 2 in Section 5 about the positivity of ⟨G⁢(r)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝐺𝑟OPEN:langle italic-G OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle\langle{G}(r)\rangle after cooling.. The results are in good agreement, although a small deviation can be observed at small distances. The suggestion of this outcome is that the three coolings affect the instanton size distribution in the small distance region in a slightly different way; the effect is however modest.

Next we compared the three coolings on a subset of the above–generated thermal equilibrium ensemble for the CP33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3} model. To this aim, we have chosen from the thermal ensemble several configurations showing non–zero topological charge after 30 iterations of the standard cooling and compared their action density and topological charge density distributions by eye to those of the same configurations cooled by 33 iterations of the Pisa cooling and by the new cooling with δ=0.007𝛿0.007italic-delta RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.007\delta=0.007. For all the configurations considered, we observed that the bumps corresponding to instantons and anti-instantons had the same shape, number and location (see Fig. 7 for an example).

These considerations provide evidence that the three cooling methods defined in Section 3 behave essentially in an equivalent way, not only on average, but also configuration by configuration, and that they can be related by a simple correspondence between number of iterations (standard and Pisa coolings) and δ𝛿italic-delta\delta (new cooling).

We close this Section with some considerations about the usual picture of cooling as a diffusion process. As we pointed out in Section 3, the parameter δ𝛿italic-delta\delta in the new cooling behaves, in the continuum limit, like a physical quantity of dimension two. Therefore, indicating with r0subscript𝑟0italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{0} the physical scale up to which cooling affects the quantum fluctuations and following Ref. [5], we infer that r0∝δ-1/2proportional-tosubscript𝑟0superscript𝛿12italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:proportional-to italic-delta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endr_{0}\propto\delta^{-1/2} in the continuum limit. On the other hand, the standard cooling is usually believed to act as a diffusion process, so that, if n𝑛italic-nn is the number of iterations, it should affect fluctuations up to a scale r0∝n1/2proportional-tosubscript𝑟0superscript𝑛12italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:proportional-to italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endr_{0}\propto n^{1/2}. Using the relation found between n𝑛italic-nn and δ𝛿italic-delta\delta, we can check both these predictions: indeed we expect that δ∝1/nproportional-to𝛿1𝑛italic-delta RELOP:proportional-to NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-n\delta\propto 1/n. In Fig. 8 we have plotted the function δ⁢(n)𝛿𝑛italic-delta OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:)\delta(n) given in Table 1, together with a best fit to a function proportional to 1/n1𝑛NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-n1/n. For the lattice parameters used in the simulation we see that δ⁢(n)𝛿𝑛italic-delta OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:)\delta(n) behaves as expected for small values of n𝑛italic-nn, while the relation δ∝1/nproportional-to𝛿1𝑛italic-delta RELOP:proportional-to NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-n\delta\propto 1/n breaks down for n≳30-40greater-than-or-equivalent-to𝑛3040italic-n RELOP:greater-than-or-equivalent-to NUMBER:30 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:40n\gtrsim 30-40, indicating that the picture of the standard cooling as a diffusion process may work well only for moderately small values of n𝑛italic-nn.

In this Section we apply the new cooling method to the determination of the physical topological susceptibility and compare the results to those from an alternative approach, the field theoretical method [18] combined with smearing [19]. As for the comparison of the new cooling with the standard and Pisa coolings, we have already shown in the previous Section that they give equivalent results for χLsuperscript𝜒𝐿italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{L}.

The lattice discretization of the topological charge density and of the topological susceptibility has already been discussed in Section 2. In the relation existing between the lattice topological susceptibility χLsuperscript𝜒𝐿italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{L} and the continuum one, Eq. (10), M⁢(β)𝑀𝛽italic-M OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)M(\beta) indicates the mixings of χLsuperscript𝜒𝐿italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{L} to operators with the same quantum numbers. More precisely one can write

semantics.annotation: italic-M OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-A OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:) italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:langle italic-T CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start np POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-P OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:) OPEN:langle italic-I CLOSE:rangle ADDOP:plus italic-O OPEN:( italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: The first and second terms in the r.h.s. are the mixings with the trace of the energy–momentum tensor and with the unit operator respectively (“np” means the purely non–perturbative part of ⟨T⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑇OPEN:langle italic-T CLOSE:rangle\langle T\rangle).

The mixing coefficients A⁢(β)𝐴𝛽italic-A OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)A(\beta) and P⁢(β)𝑃𝛽italic-P OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)P(\beta) as well as the multiplicative renormalization Z⁢(β)𝑍𝛽italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)Z(\beta) can be calculated in perturbation theory. The perturbative series for A⁢(β)𝐴𝛽italic-A OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)A(\beta) starts from the order 1/β31superscript𝛽3NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end1/\beta^{3} and arguments can be given [11] which justify that A⁢(β)⁢a2⁢⟨T⟩np𝐴𝛽superscript𝑎2subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑇npitalic-A OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:) italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:langle italic-T CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start np POSTSUBSCRIPT:endA(\beta)\,a^{2}\langle T\rangle_{\rm np} is safely negligible in the scaling window of the simulation. In Ref. [20] the perturbative series for Z⁢(β)𝑍𝛽italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)Z(\beta) has been calculated up to the order 1/β21superscript𝛽2NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end1/\beta^{2} and the perturbative series of P⁢(β)𝑃𝛽italic-P OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)P(\beta) at the first two non–zero orders 1/β41superscript𝛽4NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end1/\beta^{4} and 1/β51superscript𝛽5NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end1/\beta^{5}. On the other hand there are no available perturbative estimates of the O⁢(a4)𝑂superscript𝑎4italic-O OPEN:( italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)O(a^{4}) terms in Eq.(24).

However, a more powerful, purely numerical technique can be used to get a non–perturbative determination of Z⁢(β)𝑍𝛽italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)Z(\beta) and of the whole additive renormalization M⁢(β)𝑀𝛽italic-M OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)M(\beta). This technique is the so–called “heating method” [21].

The idea of the heating method is to determine the average values of topological quantities on samples of configurations obtained by thermalizing the short–range fluctuations, which are responsible for the renormalizations, on configurations of well defined topological background. For instance if one applies several thermalization steps at a given value of β𝛽italic-beta\beta on a configuration containing one discretized instanton of charge Q=1𝑄1italic-Q RELOP:equals NUMBER:1Q=1 and measures the average value of QLsuperscript𝑄𝐿italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{L}, then the renormalization constant Z⁢(β)𝑍𝛽italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)Z(\beta) can be determined as Z⁢(β)=⟨QL⟩/Q𝑍𝛽delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑄𝐿𝑄italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPEN:langle italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle MULOP:divide italic-QZ(\beta)=\langle Q^{L}\rangle/Q (here ⟨⋅⟩delimited-⟨⟩⋅OPEN:langle MULOP:cdot CLOSE:rangle\langle\cdot\rangle indicates an average in the background of a fixed charge Q𝑄italic-QQ). Analogously, by thermalizing a trivial configuration (for example a configuration where for all lattice sites x𝑥italic-xx, the respective fields are z⁢(x)=(1,0,0,…)𝑧𝑥100…italic-z OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPEN:( NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, ID:dots CLOSE:)z(x)=(1,0,0,\dots) and λμ⁢(x)=1subscript𝜆𝜇𝑥1italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\lambda_{\mu}(x)=1) at a given β𝛽italic-beta\beta and measuring the average value of χLsuperscript𝜒𝐿italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{L}, one gets a determination of M⁢(β)𝑀𝛽italic-M OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)M(\beta). In the first case one obtains a non–perturbative estimate of Z⁢(β)𝑍𝛽italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)Z(\beta) as long as the MS¯¯MSOVERACCENT:overline ARG:start ATOM:MS ARG:end\overline{\hbox{MS}} value of the background topological charge Q𝑄italic-QQ is chosen (see Section 2). In the second case the method amounts to impose the requirement that the physical susceptibility χ𝜒italic-chi\chi vanishes in the absence of instantons.

The heating method has been extensively applied in the following. Once all the renormalization constants are known, the extraction of χ𝜒italic-chi\chi from Eq. (10) is possible and the result is called the field theoretical determination.

img.figcaption: Figure 9: χcoolLsubscriptsuperscript𝜒𝐿coolitalic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cool POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\chi^{L}_{\mathrm{cool}} as a function of the δ𝛿italic-delta\delta parameter of the new cooling for CP99FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:9 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{9} at β=0.70𝛽0.70italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.70\beta=0.70 on a 242superscript242NUMBER:24 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end24^{2} lattice.

div.p: Since the continuum χ𝜒italic-chi\chi is extracted from the lattice χLsuperscript𝜒𝐿italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{L} by subtracting the renormalization effects, it happens that, if M⁢(β)𝑀𝛽italic-M OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)M(\beta) is a large part of the whole lattice signal and Z⁢(β)𝑍𝛽italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)Z(\beta) is small, the physical signal for χ𝜒italic-chi\chi is extracted with very large errors. This is the case when one uses the lattice discretization of Eq. (6). However, since both Z⁢(β)𝑍𝛽italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)Z(\beta) and M⁢(β)𝑀𝛽italic-M OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)M(\beta) depend on the discretization qL⁢(x)superscript𝑞𝐿𝑥italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)q^{L}(x), one can exploit the arbitrariness in the lattice definition and use an improved operator. To this aim, following the idea of Ref. [19], already used for the determination of χ𝜒italic-chi\chi in Yang–Mills theories [22], we have used a smeared topological charge density operator, which is built from the original operator qL⁢(x)superscript𝑞𝐿𝑥italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)q^{L}(x), defined in Eq. (6), by replacing the fields z⁢(x)𝑧𝑥italic-z OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)z(x) and λμ⁢(x)subscript𝜆𝜇𝑥italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)\lambda_{\mu}(x) with

div.p: where 𝒩zsubscript𝒩𝑧caligraphic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\mathcal{N}}_{z}, 𝒩λsubscript𝒩𝜆caligraphic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\mathcal{N}_{\lambda}} are normalization constants which allow that ||zsmear⁢(x)||=||λμsmear⁢(x)||=1normsuperscript𝑧smear𝑥normsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝜇smear𝑥1VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start smear POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| RELOP:equals VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start smear POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| RELOP:equals NUMBER:1||z^{\rm smear}(x)||=||\lambda_{\mu}^{\rm smear}(x)||=1 and c𝑐italic-cc has been chosen to be equal to 0.65absent\;444This choice has been based on the fact that i) it is convenient to take c𝑐italic-cc as large as possible and ii) for c>2/3𝑐23italic-c RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:2 MULOP:divide NUMBER:3c>2/3 the smearing procedure behaves in a radically different way, leading, when iterated, to a completely disordered field configuration instead of a smoother one. A similar behavior has been observed in Yang–Mills theories [23].. The smearing can be iterated at will by defining the n𝑛italic-nn–th level of smeared fields from the (n-1)𝑛1OPEN:( italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:)(n-1)–th level in an analogous fashion as shown in Eq. (25). For each level of smearing a relation like Eq. (10) holds although Z⁢(β)𝑍𝛽italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)Z(\beta) and M⁢(β)𝑀𝛽italic-M OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)M(\beta) change. Using smeared operators these renormalization constants get closer to 1 and 0, respectively, as the smearing level increases, thus allowing a much more precise determination of χ𝜒italic-chi\chi.

We performed a numerical simulation for the CP99FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:9 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{9} model at several values of β𝛽italic-beta\beta and L𝐿italic-LL. We used the same updating algorithm of the previous Section. For most simulations we collected 100K equilibrium configurations after discarding 10K configurations to allow thermalization. The successive equilibrium configurations were decorrelated by 10 updating steps. By averaging on the thermal equilibrium ensemble we determined the unsmeared lattice topological susceptibility χLsuperscript𝜒𝐿italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{L} and the smeared ones, χsmearLsubscriptsuperscript𝜒𝐿smearitalic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start smear POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\chi^{L}_{\mathrm{smear}}, for 1 to 10 smearing levels. These results, together with Z⁢(β)𝑍𝛽italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)Z(\beta) and M⁢(β)𝑀𝛽italic-M OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)M(\beta) coming from the heating method, allow to extract a2⁢χsuperscript𝑎2𝜒italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-chia^{2}\chi from Eq. (10).

Every 50 updating steps we have also applied the new cooling method at several values of the δ𝛿italic-delta\delta parameter ranging from 0.3 to 5×10-45superscript104NUMBER:5 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end5\times 10^{-4}. Since cooling eliminates the short–distance fluctuations, the value of χLsuperscript𝜒𝐿italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{L} after cooling, hereafter called χcoolLsubscriptsuperscript𝜒𝐿coolitalic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cool POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\chi^{L}_{\mathrm{cool}}, can be written as in Eq. (10) with Z≈1𝑍1italic-Z RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1Z\approx 1 and M≈0𝑀0italic-M RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0M\approx 0 if the cooling has been protracted enough. Hence it should provide directly a2⁢χsuperscript𝑎2𝜒italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-chia^{2}\chi. Consistency requires that the cooling and the field theoretical methods provide the same result.

figure.figcaption: Figure 10: Scaling of the topological susceptibility of CP99FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:9 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{9} from the field theoretical with smearing (left) and from the new cooling (right). Data points have been slightly shifted along the β𝛽italic-beta\beta axis for the sake of readability.

div.p: The summary of the performed simulations is presented in Table 2. In Fig. 9 we show the results for χcoolLsubscriptsuperscript𝜒𝐿coolitalic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cool POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\chi^{L}_{\rm cool} from the new cooling at several values for the δ𝛿italic-delta\delta parameter at β=0.70𝛽0.70italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.70\beta=0.70 on a 242superscript242NUMBER:24 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end24^{2} lattice. We interpret the behavior under the new cooling in the following way: as δ𝛿italic-delta\delta decreases, the cooling erases an even larger amount of quantum fluctuations thus bringing χcoolLsubscriptsuperscript𝜒𝐿coolitalic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cool POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\chi^{L}_{\rm cool} to a maximum. Afterwards, for too small values of δ𝛿italic-delta\delta, the cooling begins to affect also the topological fluctuations and part of the topological signal gets lost. These considerations suggest that a convenient choice of the δ𝛿italic-delta\delta parameter may be around the value for which χcoolLsubscriptsuperscript𝜒𝐿coolitalic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cool POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\chi^{L}_{\rm cool} reaches the maximum. At this value of δ𝛿italic-delta\delta we then assume that Z≈1𝑍1italic-Z RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1Z\approx 1 and M≈0𝑀0italic-M RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0M\approx 0. The choice of a smaller value for δ𝛿italic-delta\delta would not be dramatically dangerous, but would push the scaling region towards larger values of β𝛽italic-beta\beta.

In Table 3 we summarize the results for χLsuperscript𝜒𝐿italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{L} and for ξG2⁢χsuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝐺2𝜒italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-chi\xi_{G}^{2}\,\chi obtained for CP99FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:9 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{9} by the field theoretical method combined with smearing (0, 5 and 10 levels). In Table 4 the results for χcoolLsubscriptsuperscript𝜒𝐿coolitalic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cool POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\chi^{L}_{\mathrm{cool}} and ξG2⁢χsubscriptsuperscript𝜉2𝐺𝜒italic-xi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-chi\xi^{2}_{G}\,\chi obtained by the new cooling method for δ𝛿italic-delta\delta around the peak value (see Fig. 9 for β=0.70𝛽0.70italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.70\beta=0.70) are shown. Fig. 10 displays the scaling of ξG2⁢χsuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝐺2𝜒italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-chi\xi_{G}^{2}\,\chi for the cases of 0, 5 and 10 smearing levels and the field theoretical method (left) and with the new cooling method for δ𝛿italic-delta\delta=0.0100, 0.0050, 0.0025 (right). From this figure we see that there is practically no dependence on the smearing level, although error bars strongly decrease with the number of smearing levels. As for the cooling method, we see that there is a satisfying consistence among the results for the different values of δ𝛿italic-delta\delta and also between these results and those from the field theoretical method.

The study of the topological properties of the vacuum of a field theory simulated on a lattice is made difficult by the presence of quantum fluctuations which hinder the extraction of the relevant physical information. Among other methods, cooling has been proposed as a technique to wash out such fluctuations and reveal the topological background of any single field configuration. In the present paper we have made a comparison among three different cooling methods using as test–field the 2d CPN-1𝑁1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1} model defined in Section 2.

The three cooling methods under study have been defined in Section 3. They are: the standard cooling (a local minimization of the Euclidean lattice action), the Pisa cooling (the same but with local minimizations constrained to be smaller than a given bound) and a new cooling (recently introduced in Ref. [5]) where the local minimizations are accepted only if they are larger than a given bound.

Firstly, we have studied the performance of the three coolings on classical non–equi-librium configurations representing 1–instanton solutions and instanton–anti-instanton pairs. We have placed one such object on the lattice and have performed a series of cooling iterations in order to measure several physical (topological and non–topological) observables. In all situations the three coolings have yielded the same result —see Figs. 2 and 3.

After these results, we have assumed that the three cooling methods are equivalent and that a correspondence can be established between them in the sense that a given number of iterations of the Pisa or the standard coolings corresponds to a precise value for the bound in the new cooling if the value of the energy E𝐸italic-EE, Eq. (21), is the same after applying the coolings. This correspondence has been used in the subsequent investigation and, for the CP33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3} model at β=1.05𝛽1.05italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.05\beta=1.05 on a 762superscript762NUMBER:76 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end76^{2} lattice, it is shown in Table 1.

We have studied the performance of the cooling methods on a set of equilibrium configurations obtained after a Monte Carlo simulation. On these thermalized configurations we have first extracted several physical quantities after applying cooling: the lattice topological susceptibility is the same when equivalent amounts of cooling, in the sense of Table 1, are applied —see Fig. 4. The same happens for the magnetic susceptibility and for the correlation length as far as the cooling iteration is not protracted too much —see Fig. 5. The same agreement is seen for the shell correlation function ⟨G⁢(r)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝐺𝑟OPEN:langle italic-G OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle\langle G(r)\rangle if r/a𝑟𝑎italic-r MULOP:divide italic-ar/a is large enough —see Fig. 6. Then we have peered the action density and the topological charge density distributions obtained with the application of equivalent amounts of cooling, in the sense of Table 1. In all cases we have again obtained completely analogous distributions —see Fig. 7 for an example. These results altogether strongly suggest that the three cooling methods, although different in the procedure, behave equivalently.

By using the correspondence given in Table 1 we have tested the picture of cooling as a diffusion process. For the lattice parameters used in this analysis, this picture works well only for a moderately small number of iterations (n≲40less-than-or-similar-to𝑛40italic-n RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:40n\lesssim 40).

Finally we have compared the results obtained for the topological susceptibility in the CP99FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:9 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{9} model by the new cooling method with those extracted from a well–tested method: the so–called field theoretical method improved with smearing. In Tables 3 and 4 we give the results for the quantity ξG2⁢χsuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝐺2𝜒italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-chi\xi_{G}^{2}\,\chi. They agree fairly well among them, see Fig. 10, and also with the large N𝑁italic-NN estimate [24] which provides ξG2⁢χ=153superscriptsubscript𝜉𝐺2𝜒153italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-chi RELOP:equals NUMBER:153\xi_{G}^{2}\,\chi=153 up to order O⁢(1/N2)𝑂1superscript𝑁2italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-N POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)O(1/N^{2}).

We used the standard action both to generate thermal equilibrium configurations in Monte Carlo simulations and during the cooling procedure. We expect that the above results concerning the equivalence between the different cooling techniques should not depend strongly on the action used during cooling. However the comparison of the three cooling techniques by using different lattice actions is worth to be pursued in a future work.
We would like to thank P. Cea, Ph. de Forcrand, A. Di Giacomo, P. Rossi, I.O. Stamatescu and E. Vicari for useful discussions.
